awd_titl_txt: Developing Pre-service Science Teachers' Pedagogical Content Knowledge for Engineering Design Integrated Science Teaching, and Assessing the Impact on Student Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The current US National framework for K-12 science education requires teachers to teach science through engineering design. However, many science teachers have no training in this area. Therefore, there is an urgent need to train teachers in the concepts of engineering design and methods for teaching it. There is also a need to collect research evidence on how teachers develop knowledge for teaching science through engineering design and the effect of their teaching practices on student learning. This research project is training pre-service science teachers in engineering design, developing their knowledge for teaching science through engineering design, and assessing the impact on their students' learning of and attitudes towards engineering design and science. Results from the project are providing research evidence on the development of pre-service teachers' knowledge of teaching science through engineering design, the resulting instructional practices, and the impact on student learning and attitude towards engineering design and science. This project will impact at least 1000 high school students directly, teaching them principle of engineering design. The impact of the project will be further magnified through the development of a manual on effective approaches for teaching engineering design in high schools. Ultimately, the goal of the project is to provide proven resources for preparing the future workforce for engineering challenges of the future.

The New Framework for K-12 Science Education, and the Next Generation Science Education Standards accentuate the integration of engineering design in K-12 science classrooms. However, many science teachers lack knowledge of engineering design.  Likewise, there is a paucity of research on science teachers' pedagogical content knowledge of engineering design integrated science (EDIS) teaching, and its effect on student achievement in engineering design and science. Clearly, the success of engineering design in K-12 science will largely depend on teachers' understanding of engineering design and their pedagogical content knowledge of EDIS teaching. Therefore, this study is addressing four objectives: train high school pre-service science teachers in engineering design; measure the development of the pre-service science teachers' pedagogical content knowledge of engineering design integrated science instruction; facilitate pre-service teachers' implementation of EDIS units in high schools; and assess the effect of the pre-service teachers' pedagogical content knowledge of engineering integrated science instruction on students' learning of and attitudes towards engineering design and science. The sample is comprised of two cohorts of 34 pre-service science teachers and 1428 high school students. The project is employing a two-cohort cluster randomized trial with repeated measures design of pre- and post-measures, where high school science classes serve as the cluster level.  Each pre-service teacher is teaching two science classes in high schools. Two classes nested within each pre-service teacher are divided into two groups, Traditional group and Engineering Design group. The Traditional group serves as a baseline for comparison to the Engineering Design group. Data is being collected using the Pedagogical Content Knowledge of EDIS Science Teaching instrument, the Engineering Design Skills and Engineering Design Attitudes questionnaire, Knowledge Integration Content Knowledge tests, the Engineering Design Process Knowledge Instrument, and the revised Reformed Teaching Observation Protocol (RTOP). Multilevel and structural equation modeling and analytic induction are the data analysis techniques. The results will provide empirical evidence on the development of pre-service teachers' pedagogical content knowledge of EDIS teaching, the resulting instructional practices, and the impact on student learning and attitude towards engineering design and science. The project will significantly impact pre-service science teachers' engineering design skills, instructional practice, and student learning and attitude towards engineering design.

por.por_cntn:
The New Framework for K-12 Science Education, Next Generation Science Education Standards accentuate the integration of engineering design in K-12 science. Therefore, K-12 science teachers are required to teach both engineering design and science content knowledge. However, many science teachers lack the knowledge for integrating engineering design in science teaching they have not received training in engineering design.  Likewise, there was a paucity of research on science teachers pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) of engineering design integrated science (EDIS) teaching and its effect on student learning in engineering design integrated science instruction. Yet, the success of engineering design in K-12 science will largely depend on teachers understanding of engineering design and their PCK of EDIS teaching. Therefore, this research project prepared 67 high school pre-service science (chemistry, physics, biology and earth science) teachers in engineering design; measured the development of the pre-service science teachers PCK of engineering design integrated science instruction;  facilitated pre-service teachers implementation of EDIS units in high schools; and assessed the effect of the pre-service teachers' engineering integrated science instruction on students learning and attitude toward engineering design. The preparation  was done in our science teacher education program. Our participant pre-service teachers developed and implemented EDIS units in schools during their student teaching. One thousand two hundred and twenty-six (1226) middle and high  students received instruction in engineering design integrated science lessons from the participant pre-service teachers. Data was collected using surveys, interviews, science and engineering design tests. We also examined the  EDIS Units participant pre-service teachers developed for the representation of science and engineering design. 

Our findings show that the pre-service teachers developed engineering design skills and sound understanding of engineering design, improved their PCK of engineering integrated science instruction, developed skills for developing engineering design integrated science units and lessons,  improved instructional practice, and showed high self-efficacy for teaching EDIS lessons. In the classrooms where our pre-service teachers implemented EDIS lessons, our findings show that students (N=1226) performed well on science content and engineering design skills that were taught. Students also developed sound understanding of engineering design process and positive perceptions of learning science through engineering design process.  As such, these findings provide the evidence that sustained pre-service science teachers training in engineering design integrated science teaching has positive impact on student learning outcomes -content, skills and attitude toward engineering design.

Thus, the intellectual merit of this project was in providing empirical evidence on the development of pre-service teachers PCK for EDIS instruction, the resulting improved instructional practices, and the impact on student learning and attitude towards engineering design. Additional merits was empirically showing how this approach can provide a valid indicator of student learning in EDIS instruction. Overall, the project has provided research evidence on how to integrate engineering design in pre-service science teacher education, and how teachers' PCK for EDIS teaching in K-12 science can be developed.

The broader impacts of this project are in the training of pre-service science teachers in engineering design, and EDIS teaching.  Our 60 participant pre-service are now trained EDIS teachers and have continued to provide engineering design instruction and instructional leadership in their science classes, schools and districts. They are also promoting engineering education in schools. Their  sound PCK of EDIS teaching will continue to impact on their skills for developing and teaching EDIS curriculum, and subsequently increase student learning in engineering design and science. This model for integrating engineering design in pre-service science teacher education program is transferable to other institutions. EDIS materials we have developed and tested in our project are available for free to other institutions and school districts.

Overall, the project significantly impacted on pre-service science teachers' engineering design skills, EDIS curriculum development skills, instructional practice, and middle and high school student learning and their attitude towards engineering design.
